content:
Quick question for notation gurus: we (already) have a declaration LSeries with type (ℕ → ℂ) → ℂ → ℂ, i.e. its output is a number. (By Mathlib's conventions this should probably be called lSeries or even lseries, but the capital L is standard in informal math so an exception has been made; that's not the question here).

Now, PR #11214 adds lemmas about the linearity properties of LSeries in the ℕ → ℂ argument. What should these be called? Am I correct in believing that LSeries.add, LSeries.smul would be discouraged, since this is not a situation where dot-notation makes sense?
@Michael Stoll @Ruben Van de Velde

My 2 cents:

  • I'd strongly prefer to not lower-case LSeries in places where this is at the beginning of a name that #naming wants to be in lowerCamelCase. There are only L-series and no l-series in (informal) math.
  • By analogy with HasSum, Summable and tsum, I would think the correct names should be LSeriesHasSum.add, LSeriesSummable.add and LSeries_add (or, if need be, lseries_add:frown:). (And similarly for neg and smul.)

In any case, I'd like to get a consensus on this point soon, so that I can continue the process of moving results on L-series into Mathlib.

There are only L-series and no l-series in (informal) math.

Indeed, but we're not doing informal math here. Sage modular form objects have had a method cuspform_lseries for years and nobody seems to have been bothered by it (at least, not enough to change it). But the capitalisation of LSeries is not the question here (it is not a new declaration introduced in #11214 so it is irrelevant to the reviewing of that PR).
